title: Vicente Saadi
text:
Vicente Leonidas Saadi (1913 – 10 July 1988) was an <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="Justicialist%20Party">Justicialist Party</a> politician. He was a <a href="Argentine%20Senate">senator</a> and governor for <a href="Catamarca%20Province">Catamarca Province</a>, and became the patriarch of a family that has dominated Catamarca politics since the 1940s.
Born in <a href="Bel%C3%A9n%2C%20Catamarca">Belén</a>, his family were prosperous <a href="Syria">Syria</a>n immigrants who became prominent in local <a href="commerce">commerce</a>. He allied himself with the centrist <a href="Radical%20Civic%20Union">Radical Civic Union</a> (UCR) early on, though after the rise of populist leader <a href="Juan%20Per%C3%B3n">Juan Perón</a> in 1945, he switched allegiances for the latter.
Saadi was elected Senator in 1946, serving until 1949 when he was elected on the <a href="Peronist">Peronist</a> ticket as Governor of Catamarca. The party's leader, President Perón, ordered Saadi removed from his post after four months, however, amid allegations of "<a href="nepotism">nepotism</a> and despotism" in his administration of the remote province. Saadi was subsequently expelled from the party, and served time in prison.
He was married to Alicia Cubas de Saadi, and a number of their children went on to become leading Catamarca Province figures, as well. <a href="Ram%C3%B3n%20Saadi">Ramón Saadi</a> was elected governor of Catamarca in 1987, <a href="Alicia%20Saadi">Alicia Saadi</a> was elected to the Senate in 1999, and <a href="Vicente%20Saadi%20%28younger%29">Vicente Saadi</a> (jr) and his daughter-in-law.
He was ultimately re-elected to the Senate in 1973 on behalf of the Peronist-led <a href="Justicialist%20Party">Frejuli</a> alliance, serving until the dissolution of the <a href="Argentine%20Senate">Argentine Senate</a> in the <a href="March%201976%20coup">March 1976 coup</a>. In the 1970s Saadi had been a leading supporter of the far-left <a href="Montoneros">Montoneros</a>, and set up the "Intransigencia y Movilización" faction; he was a patron of future Defense Minister <a href="Nilda%20Garr%C3%A9">Nilda Garré</a>.
<a href="1983%20Argentine%20general%20election">Re-elected in 1983</a> at the return of democracy, Saadi led the Justicialists in the Senate, where the party obtained a majority of 21 seats to 18 for the UCR. Saadi abandoned his earlier support for left-wing Peronists, and endorsed <a href="Herminio%20Iglesias">Herminio Iglesias</a> as candidate in the race for <a href="Governor%20of%20Buenos%20Aires">Governor of Buenos Aires</a> (the nation's largest province). Iglesias, a right-wing Peronist, lost the race, and despite the miscalculation, Saadi was elected Vice-President of the party. In that capacity, he worked closely with the leader of the UCR, President-elect <a href="Raul%20Alfons%C3%ADn">Raul Alfonsín</a>, during the transition to democracy.
Saadi later took part in a famous television debate with <a href="Dante%20Caputo">Dante Caputo</a> on November 14, 1984, arguing against the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Peace%20and%20Friendship%20of%201984%20between%20Chile%20and%20Argentina">Treaty of Peace and Friendship of 1984 between Chile and Argentina</a>. In 1987 he swapped jobs with his son, Ramón, becoming governor once again whilst his son became a Senator. He remained powerful in the party, and that year, decided that the Justicialist Party would not pay the $8 million ransom demanded for the return of the <a href="Hands%20of%20Per%C3%B3n">hands of Juan Perón</a>, which had been stolen in June or July of that year. Vicente died in office.
Saadi was a leading figure in the politics of his province and the left-wing of his party, serving as vice-President of the <a href="Peronist">Peronist</a>s and considered a "<a href="caudillo">caudillo</a>" for his manner of control. He was one of the first prominent <a href="Syrian">Syrian</a>-Argentines and his name is recorded in streets, squares and other institutions around the country.
